questions.text: You are posted in Covid ward where you receive a patient of Covid ARDS with spo2-90% and respiratory rate of 28. Which of the following will not be very useful in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Nasal canula will not be useful in moderate COVID cases due to low FiO2.
  • High flow nasal canula or non invasive ventilation is preferred in this case.
  • If patient doesn't respond, invasive ventilation is required.

Reference- Miller's anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 2595

questions.text: The lab reports of a patient given below: pH= 7.2, HCO3=10, mEq/L PCO2-30 mmHg. This exemplifies which of the following disorder?
questions.solution:
Normal pH is 7.35 to 7.45 (7.40), pCO2 is 35 to 45 mm Hg (40 mm Hg) & Bicarbonate level is 22 to 26 mmol/L (24 mmol/L).

Option A: In Respiratory acidosis, pH is low, pCO2 is high & bicarbonate is high.

Option B: In Respiratory alkalosis, pH is high, pCO2 is low & bicarbonate is low.

Option C: In Metabolic acidosis, pH is low, pCO2 is low & bicarbonate is low.

Option D: In Metabolic alkalosis, pH is high, pCO2 is high & bicarbonate is high.

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal medicine 21st edition CH 55 PN 359

questions.text: A woman presenting with acne which is resistant to multiple cycles of antibiotics and non responsive to oral. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
This patient is having mandibular acne, which is seen in hormonal imbalance. Hormonal acne are not responsive to oral antibiotics. Thus, patient should be assessed for hyperandrogenism.

Most common cause of hyperandrogenism is polycystic ovarian syndrome.

Two syndromes associated with hyperandrogenism:

SAHA syndrome- Seborrhoea, Acne, Hirsutism and Alopecia

HAIRAN syndrome:

  • HA- Hyperandrogenism
  • IR- Insulin resistance
  • AN- Acanthosis nigricans

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

questions.text: A man who is chronic alcoholic will develop which type of cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is due to sarcomere gene mutation.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is due to either infiltrative diseases or fibrosis of the myocardium.

Dialated cardiomyopathy has varied etiologies, which include infections, toxins including alcohol, metabolic and nutritional deficiencies including thiamine and familial causes.

Takosubo cardiomyopathy is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy characterised by apical ballooning and is seen in extreme emotional or physical stress.

In the give question, the patient being an alcoholic, he is prone for a toxic cardiomyopathy as well as due to chronic thiamine deficiency , both of which lead to dilated cardiomyopathy

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed pg 1954-1959

questions.text: A pregnant woman, whose niece contracted varicella is in the same house was negative for serum antibodies for varicella, this would mean?
questions.solution:
Chicken pox is caused by varicella zoster virus

Incubation period is 10-21 days

Infection is acquired through respiratory tract via air droplets or rarely from conjunctiva. Infectious period ( Communicable period) for chicken pox is 2 days prior to 5 days after onset of rash with very high secondary attack rate of 90 %.

Clinical feature has two stages

  • Pre eruptive stage - characterized by fever, back pain,malaise and shivering
  • Eruptive phase - Has characteristic rash with following feature Superficial and unilocular ( Rash of small pox is deep seated and multilocular) Symmetrical, mostly on flexor surface ( Rash of small pox usually affect extensor surface) Centripetal distribution - (Rash of small pox has centrifugal distribution) Affect axilla but spares palm and sole - ( small pox affect palms and soles but spares axilla)

Pleomorphic with appearance of all stages of rash simultaneously ( Rash is non monomorphic in nature in small pox)

Dew drop on rose petal appearance ( Rash of small pox has umbilicated appearance )

Area of inflammation around the rash ( In small pox there is no inflammation around the rash)

Evolution of rash is rapid, scabs begin to form 4-7 days after rash ( Evolution is slow , scab begin 10-14 after rash in small pox)

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th ed 477

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not derived from external oblique muscle fibres.
questions.solution:
• The inguinal or Poupart's ligament is formed by the lower border of the external oblique aponeurosis which is thickened and folded backwards on itself.
  • Extension of inguinal ligament:
    • The pectineal part of the inguinal ligament or lacunar ligament is triangular.
    • The pectineal ligament or ligament of Cooper is an extension from the posterior part of the base of the lacunar ligament. It is attached to the pecten pubis.
    • The reflected part of the inguinal ligament consists of fibres that pass upwards and medially from the lateral crus of the superficial inguinal ring.
    • Intercrural fibres arise from the middle of the inguinal ligament, arch over the superficial inguinal ring to keep its crura together.
  • A few centimetres lateral to the median furrow, the abdominal wall shows a curved vertical groove. Its upper end reaches the costal margin at the tip of the ninth costal cartilage. Inferiorly, it reaches the pubic tubercle. This line is called the linea semilunaris.
    • It corresponds to the lateral margin of a muscle called the rectus abdominis.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-3, 8th Edition, Page No - 234, 242, 243

questions.text: A child presented with refractory anemia. The smear of bone marrow biopsy of the child showed cells with a wrinkled tissue pattern.. The probable enzyme deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Beta glucocerebrosidase deficiency leads to Gaucher disease, which is characterized by enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants.

Option B: Lysosomal α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency can leads to Pompe disease. It is glycogen storage disease which is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes: juvenile-onset variant, muscle hypotonia, death from heart failure by age 2; adult-onset variant, muscle dystrophy.

Option C: Hexosaminidase A deficiency can leads to Tay sach disease, characterized by mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness.

Option D: Hexosaminidase B deficiency can leads to Sandhoff's disease.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 24 PN 235

questions.text: A patient with diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia. Which nutrition deficiency causes this?
questions.solution:
Pellagra is clinically manifested by the 4 D' s: photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death.

Pellagra is a disease of a maize and jowar-eating population.Amino-acid imbalance caused by an excess of leucine is the cause of pellagra in both jowar and maize eaters. Excess of leucine appears to interfere in the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

Malabsorption syndromes (jejunoileitis, gastroenterostomy, subtotal gastrectomy, Crohn′s disease), chronic alcoholism, metabolic derangements (Hartnup disease, carcinoid syndrome), and drugs (INH, 6-mercaptopurine, 5-fluorouracil, pyrazinamide, phenytoin, chloramphenicol, azathioprine, phenobarbitone, ethionamide) are the causes of pellagra.

Dermatitis over photoexposed site of body. eczematous lesions over neck also known as 'casal's necklace'.

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

questions.text: The injury is suggestive of
questions.solution:
DEFENCE WOUNDS : Defence wounds result due to the immediate and instinctive reaction of the victim to save himself. They are classified into two types:

  1. Active defence wounds are caused when the victim tries to grasp the weapon.
  2. Passive defence wounds are caused when the victim raises the hands, arms or legs. When attacked with blunt object, most persons will attempt to protect their eyes, head and neck by raising their arms, flexing their elbows and covering the head and neck, or try to grasp the weapon. As a result bruises and abrasions are produced on the extensor or ulnar surfaces of the forearms, wrists, backs of the hands, knuckles and lateral/posterior aspects of the upper arms.

In stabbing with a single-edged weapon, if the weapon is grasped, a single cut is produced on the palm of the hand or on the bends of the fingers or thumb. If the weapon is double-edged, cuts are produced both on the palm and fingers. When attacked, the victim usually holds up the hand or forearm and receives cuts on the hand, wrist, ulnar border of the forearm and on the fingers. A typical knife defence wound may be seen in the web between the base of the thumb and index finger, when the blade is grasped. Defence wounds indicate homicide. In the female, they suggest sexual assault.

Offensive Manual Injuries: Abrasions and contusions over the knuckles can be sustained due to offensive efforts by the victim, or by his defensive efforts. Ragged knuckle lacerations on the victim indicate that his fist struck the assailant's anterior teeth when he struck a blow on the latter's open mouth. Fractures of the fourth and fifth metacarpals (knuckle fractures) may occur when the assailant is punched on his head or chin. In manual assault, the hands of the suspected assailant may show injuries indicative of or compatible with his involvement in assault.

SELF-INFLICTED AND FABRICATED WOUNDS: Self-inflicted wounds are those inflicted by a person on his own body. Fabricated wounds (fictitious, forged or invented wounds) are those which may be produced by a person on his own body (self-inflicted), or by another with his consent.

Types of wounds : Fabricated wounds are mostly incised wounds, and sometimes contusions, stab wounds and burns. Incised wounds are usually superficial, multiple and parallel, are of equal depth at origin and termination. They avoid vital and sensitive areas like the eyes, lips, nose and ears. The direction is from behind forwards on the top of the head, from above downwards on the outer side of upper arm, from below upwards on the front of forearms, variable on the legs and vertical on the abdomen and chest. Some mentally disordered persons may inflict hundreds of small wounds upon themselves. Stab wounds are usually multiple and superficial and seen about the left arm or shoulder and sometimes on the chest. Burns are superficial and seen usually on the left upper arm. The clothes are not cut and if cuts are seen they are not compatible with the nature of the wounds. The history of the assault is incompatible with the injuries. Old linear scars in sites of election suggest previous similar attempts. They are seen on the face. On the front of the trunk, on the arms and on the fronts of the legs.

Hesitation marks or tentative cuts or trial wounds: They are cuts which are multiple, small and superficial often involving only the skin and are seen at the beginning of the incised wound

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology By K S Narayan Reddy , 35th edition.

questions.text: Recent influenza A pandemic was due to-
questions.solution:
Influenza is RNA virus. It has segmented RNA. 8 segments are there. Till now many epidemic and pandemic has occurred by various stains H5N1, H1N1 etc

Antigenic shift and antigenic drift occurs in Influenza A virus.

Antigenic shift is major change in antigenic structure and responsible for pandemic.

Antigenic drift is minor change in antigenic structure and responsible for epidemic.

This virus is present in birds and animals ( Swine). That s why it is also known as swine flu.

Recent influenza pandemic was due to H1N1.

Reference: Ananthnarayan 9th edition, page no-560.

questions.text: A elderly patient with decreasing far vision but does not need near glasses now?
questions.solution:
AETIOLOGICAL TYPES

Aetiologically, myopia may be of following types;

1.Axial myopia:- It is the commonest form. Axial Myopia results from increase in antero- posterior length of the eye ball. It is defined as an axial length above the norm and too long for the refractive power of the whole optical system of the eye. High myopia, has become one of the major causes of visual field defects, visual impairment, and blindness.

2.Curvatural myopia:- Curvatural Myopia occurs due to increased curvature of the cornea, lens or both.

It is a condition where corneal curvature is increased than normal(i.e. radius of curvature is decreased),as a result, refractive power of cornea increases and light rays meet,infront of retina.

3.Positional myopia :-Positional Myopia is produced by anterior placement of crystalline lens in the eye.

It is a condition where,the lens is abnormally placed in front of its normal location, as a result the focal point is found in front of the retina.

4.Index myopia :- Index Myopia occurs from increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens associated with nuclear sclerosis.

It happens in old age(associated with cataract),when the refractive index of lens increases,resulting in increased power of lens, so that light rays meet infront of fovea.

5 Pseudomyopia :- Pseudomyopia also known as Artificial Myopia , it may be produced in conditions such as excessive accommodation and spasm of accommodation . Pseudomyopia or Artificial myopia also develops after full hyperopic correction in children .

Reference: kurana 4/e,p. 12-26

questions.text: Identify a vocal cord which is covered with exophytic lesions:
questions.solution:
The multiple exophytic lesions on the surface of the vocal cord, which is characteristic of laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papillomas are benign growths caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and can lead to hoarseness of voice and other vocal cord-related symptoms.

Other options:

A.Reinke's Edema - Reinke's edema presents as diffuse swelling and fluid accumulation in the subepithelial layer of the vocal cord. It does not typically present as exophytic lesions.

C.Malignancy - Malignant lesions of the vocal cord may appear as irregular masses or ulcerations, but they do not typically present as multiple exophytic lesions.

D.Tracheomalacia - Tracheomalacia refers to the weakness of the tracheal cartilage, which may cause tracheal collapse during respiration.

Reference : Textbook of Ear, Nose, Throat and Head-Neck Surgery Clinical and Practical by P. Hazarika, 4th Edition, page no: 504

questions.text: A child presents with dementia, diarrhea and dermatitis. Which of the following is suspected deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy. Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen. Both this enzyme requires vitamin C. So signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss, and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis (leading to delayed wound healing), and psychological changes that can be attributed to impaired synthesis of catecholamines.

Option B: Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency can lead to pellagra. It is characterized by a photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Although the nutritional etiology of pellagra is well established, and either tryptophan or niacin prevents or cures the disease, additional factors, including deficiency of riboflavin or vitamin B6, both of which are required for synthesis of nicotinamide from tryptophan, may be important. In most outbreaks of pellagra, twice as many women as men are affected, probably the result of inhibition of tryptophan metabolism by estrogen metabolites.

Option C: Although clinical deficiency disease is rare, there is evidence that a significant proportion of the population has marginal vitamin B6 status. Moderate deficiency results in abnormalities of tryptophan and methionine metabolism. Increased sensitivity to steroid hormone action may be important in the development of hormone-dependent cancer of the breast, uterus, and prostate, and vitamin B6 status may affect the prognosis. The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro, expressed as the activation coefficient. Measurement of plasma concentrations of the vitamin is also used.

Option D: Pernicious anemia arises when vitamin B12 deficiency impairs the metabolism of folic acid, leading to functional folate deficiency that disturbs erythropoiesis, causing immature precursors of erythrocytes to be released into the circulation (megaloblastic anemia). The most common cause of pernicious anemia is failure of the absorption of vitamin B12 rather than dietary deficiency. This can be the result of failure of intrinsic factor secretion caused by autoimmune disease affecting parietal cells or from production of anti-intrinsic factor antibodies. There is irreversible degeneration of the spinal cord in pernicious anemia, as a result of failure of methylation of one arginine residue in myelin basic protein. This is occurs as result of methionine deficiency in the central nervous system, rather than secondary folate deficiency.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 44 PN 534

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in brain
questions.solution:
• Congenital cerebral aneurysms:
    • These occur mostly on the vessels of circulus arteriosus, particularly at or near the junction of two arteries involved in the formation of the circle of Willis.
    • The basic abnormality at these points is the congenital deficiency of tunica media in the arterial wall.
    • The aneurysms are berry shaped (saccular) so known as berry or saccular aneurysm.
    • The Subarachnoid haemorrhage commonly results from rupture of these aneurysms.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition, Page No - 171

questions.text: Most common opportunistic infection after renal transplant?
questions.solution:
CMV infection after transplant is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Plasma viral load and a rise in IgM is diagnostic. Treatment is Valgancyclovir.

BK polyoma virus infection occurs due to reactivation of dormant virus in the urothelial cells. It leads to graft rejection. Monitoring of viral load is needed. Renal biopsy shows interstitial nephritis, cytopathic changes of virus in tubular epithelial cells and viral antigens in the allograft. Leflunomide, Cidofovir, quinolones are effective against the viral helicase. Reduction in dose of immunosuppression is needed. IvIg has been used with questionable benefit

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed 2330-31

questions.text: The mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillins via betalactamase is by-
questions.solution:
Betalactamase is enzyme produced by bacteria which will break the penicillin ring.

Penicillin has the 'ring' structure in it. It is hexagonal structure.

Altered penicillin binding protein is not the mechanism of bacterial resisitance to penicillin via betalactamase.

Drug efflux is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via betalactamase

Allteration in 50s ribosome is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via betalactamase

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition 345

questions.text: U/L proptosis with B/L sixth nerve palsy:
questions.solution:
Proptosis is initially seen unilaterally ultimately becomes bilateral.

>6th cranial nerve(Abducent) passes through the cavernous sinus. So in cavernous sinus thrombosis bilateral abducens palsy is seen.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye -Ed. 22 Pg 312

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of motor vehicle accidents has presented to casualty with pelvic fracture. His vitals are stable, but he is unable to pass the urine. On examination, he has blood at the penile meatus. Angio has been performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury
questions.solution:
• The urethra can also rupture in accidental injuries.
  • Rupture of penile urethra leads to collection of urine in the superficial perineal space.
  • Rupture of membranous urethra causes accumulation of urine in the pelvic cavity.
  • Rupture of the urethra leads to extravasation of urine, which may be superficial or deep.
  • In superficial extravasation, the urine spreads downwards deep to the membranous layer of the superficial fascia. It first fills the superficial perineal space; and then the scrotum, the penis and the lower part of the anterior abdominal wall.
  • It is prevented from going to the ischioanal fossa or the thigh by the firm attachment of the membranous layer of superficial fascia to their boundaries.
  • In deep extravasation, the urine spreads upwards into the extraperitoneal space of the pelvis around the bladder and prostate into the anterior abdominal wall.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page No - 219, 242

questions.text: Insulin glucagon ratio is decreased, which of the following enzyme will be most active?
questions.solution:
Glucokinase, Hexokinase & Phosphofructokinase involved in glycolysis, whereas Glucose-6-phosphatase involved in gluconeogenesis.

Glycolysis & gluconeogenesis share the same pathway but in opposite directions, and are reciprocally regulated.

Glucagon and epinephrine, hormones that are responsive to a decrease in blood glucose, inhibit glycolysis and stimulate gluconeogenesis in the liver by increasing the concentration of cAMP.

Insulin glucagon ratio is decreased in fasting condition, activate glucose 6 phosphatase.

So Option D is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 19 PN 175

questions.text: A child with H/o severe pain in throat with hoarseness of voice, with high grade fever with toxic looks & presenting with clinical condition showing an ulcer in th mouth covered with a gray membrane:
questions.solution:
A grayish-white membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx, which is characteristic of diphtheria. Diphtheria is a serious bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The formation of a pseudomembrane in the throat is a hallmark feature of diphtheria. It can also cause fever, sore throat, and difficulty breathing.

Other options:

A.Membranous tonsillitis - Membranous tonsillitis can cause inflammation and swelling of the tonsils, but it is not specific to the formation of a pseudomembrane as seen in the image.

B.Follicular tonsillitis - Follicular tonsillitis presents with inflamed and enlarged tonsils with visible white or yellowish spots (follicles), but it does not typically produce a pseudomembrane.

D.Aphthous ulcer - Aphthous ulcers are small, painful sores that can develop on the mucous membranes of the mouth and throat. They are not associated with the formation of a pseudomembrane.

Reference : Textbook of Ear, Nose, Throat and Head-Neck Surgery Clinical and Practical by P. Hazarika, 4th Edition, page no: 362

questions.text: Which is not seen in ACTH deficiency?
questions.solution:
In hypoadrenalism due to ACTH deficiency, hyperpigmentation is not seen. Instead alabaster coloured pale skin is seen. In primary adrenal insufficeiency, due to POMC excess, hyperpigmentation is seen.

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed 2972

questions.text: A 30 year old man reports four hours after acquiring a clean wound without laceration. He had received TT vaccination 10 year back. What do you advice regarding tetanus prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
As it is clean wound without laceration, Person has taken TT before 10 years.

So as per guideline, he should take single dose of TT

Prevention of tetanus after injury.

All wounds must be thoroughly cleaned soon after injury- Removal of foreign body, soil, dust, necrotic tissue. This procedure abolish anaerobic conditions which favour germination of tetanus spore.

Further management depend on the immune status, type of wound and duration of wound.

A- He had complete course of toxoid or a booster dose within the past 5 years

B- Had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose more than 5 years ago and less than 10 year ago

C- Had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose more than 10 years ago.

D- Has not had a comleetecours of toxoid or immunity status is unknow.

All wound surgical toilet

  1. Would less than 6 hr old, clean, non penetrating and with negligible tissue damage
    1. IF A- nothing more required
    2. IF B- Toxoid 1 dose
    3. IF C- toxoid 1 dose
    4. IF D- Toxoid complete course
  2. Other wounds
    1. IF A- nothing more required
    2. IF B- toxoid 1 dose
    3. IF C- Toxoid 1 dose plus human immunoglobulin
    4. If D- Toxoid complete course plus human immunoglobulin

Reference: Park 19th 263, ananthnarayan 9th 267

questions.text: Loss of pain/temperature sensation on ipsilateral face & c/l body due to thrombosis in?
questions.solution:
This sensory pattern is seen in Lateral medullary syndrome. The arteries responsible may be vertebral> PICA>Superior, middle or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

So if vertebral artery is there in the option that should be the answer. Here it is given as anterior vertebral artery. So the most appropriate would be PICA.

The lateral medullary arteries are penetrating branches and lead to partial syndromes.

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed 3321

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be acquired by traumatic inoculation?
questions.solution:
Sporothrixschenki is caused by thermally dimorphic fungus sporothrixschenkii.

It is naturally found in soil, hay, sphagnum moss, and plants. It usually affects farmers, garderners and agricultural worker. This fungal disease usually affects the skin although rare forms can affect the lungs, joints, bone and CNS.

Fungus enters through small cuts and abrasion in the skin to cause the infection.

Because roses can spread the disease, it is one of a few diseases referred to as rose thorn or rose gardener's disease.

Reference: Harrison 18th ed, pn-1665

questions.text: Which of the following is an androgen-dependent pubertal change?
questions.solution:
Hair growth (pubic and axillary hair) is stimulated by androgens, mainly DHEA/DHEAS from the adrenal glands (adrenarche) and to some extent ovarian androgens.

  • Other androgen-dependent changes may include skin oiliness and acne.

Normal Pubertal Development in Females

Age of Onset of Puberty


Usual Sequence of Pubertal Changes in Females


Tanner Staging of Female Puberty


Explanation for other options:

Menarche (Option B): Initiated by oestrogen and progesterone as part of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Not androgen-dependent.

Vaginal cornification (Option C): Caused by oestrogen, stimulates the stratified squamous epithelium of the vagina.

Cervical mucus changes (Option D): Regulated by oestrogen and progesterone, especially across the menstrual cycle.

Reference: Review of Gynaecology by Dr.Shakshi Arora Hans, 9th Edition, Page 78

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign in:
questions.solution:
In exudative retinal detachment, the subretinal fluid may be confined to a localized area, usually the posterior pole, or may extend to the periphery, even forming bullous retinal detachment.

  • The characteristic feature of a significant exudative retinal detachment is the presence of shifting subretinal fluid.
  • The fluid shifts to the most dependent location when patients change body position.

Reference: Parson, Section IV, pn: 147-156

questions.text: Which of the following is the topical use of the Mitomycin C
questions.solution:
The Mitomycin C is used topically for the treatment of subglottic stenosis. Subglottic stenosis is a condition where the airway just below the vocal cords becomes narrow, leading to breathing difficulties. Mitomycin C is applied topically during endoscopic procedures to help prevent the recurrence of scar tissue formation and reduce the narrowing of the airway in cases of subglottic stenosis.

Other options :

B.Inlay type 1 myringoplasty: Mitomycin C is not used topically for myringoplasty procedures. Myringoplasty is a surgical technique to repair a perforated eardrum.

C.Post adenoidectomy to control bleeding: Mitomycin C is not commonly used topically for controlling bleeding post-adenoidectomy. Hemostatic techniques and packing are more commonly used for this purpose.

D.Rhino-cerebral mucormycosis: While Mitomycin C is an antifungal agent, it is not typically used topically for the treatment of rhino-cerebral mucormycosis. Systemic antifungal medications are the primary treatment for this severe fungal infection.

Reference: Logan Turner's Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear, Head and Neck Surgery, Edited by S. Musheer Hussain, 11th Edition, Page no. : 580

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with confusion. There is a history of fall one week back. He also has a personal history of chronic alcoholism. NCCT findings as shown below, point towards
questions.solution:
• Extradural and subdural hemorrhages are both common.
  • An extradural hemorrhage can be distinguished from a subdural hemorrhage because of the following differences.
  • The extradural hemorrhage is arterial due to injury to the middle meningeal artery, whereas subdural hemorrhage is venous in nature.
  • Symptoms of cerebral compression are late in extradural hemorrhage.
  • In an extradural hemorrhage, paralysis first appears in the face and then spreads to the lower parts of the body.
  • In a subdural hemorrhage, the progress of paralysis is haphazard.
  • In an extradural hemorrhage, there is no blood in the CSF, while it is a common feature of subdural hemorrhage.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 8th Edition, Page No - 216

questions.text: A family consuming predominantly of polished rice would present with which of the following deficiencies? Match the vitamin deficiency with the investigation used to detect the deficiency:
questions.solution:
A family consuming predominantly of polished rice likely to have thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

Option A: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. But here likely vitamin deficiency is thiamine.

Option B: Xanthurenic acid is excreted in vitamin B6 deficiency.

The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro.

Option C: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Not transketolase (used in thiamine deficiency).

Option D: Thiamine nutritional status can be assessed by erythrocyte transketolase activation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 44 PN 534

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple perforations of Tympanic Membrane. Most Probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
A tympanic membrane with multiple perforations and caseous debris in the middle ear space, which is indicative of tubercular otitis media. Tubercular otitis media is a rare form of otitis media caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in the middle ear.

Other options:

B.Syphilitic Otitis Media - Syphilitic otitis media is a manifestation of tertiary syphilis involving the middle ear structures. It typically presents with destructive changes to the middle ear bones (otosclerosis) and is less likely to cause multiple perforations

C.Pseudomonas Infection - Pseudomonas infection can cause acute otitis media with purulent discharge, but it is not typically associated with multiple perforations and caseous debris.

D.Fungal Otitis Media - Fungal otitis media is characterized by fungal infection of the middle ear space. It may present with otorrhea, but the presence of multiple perforations is not typical.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, arose and Throat, And Head and Surgery by Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page no: 81

questions.text: A patient developed vomiting 3-4 hrs after eating a meal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Incubation period of various bacterial food poisoning

    1. Improve quality of intubation

    3. Identify residual neuromuscular block
  • Peripheral nerve stimulation is done to test the function of neuromuscular junction, a peripheral nerve is stimulated electrically, and the response of the muscle is assessed.
  • Most common nerve and muscle combination used-
    • Ulnar nerve and adductor pollicis muscle
    • 2nd most common is facial nerve and orbicularis oculi muscle

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5931185/, Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 1356

questions.text: A male patient presenting with complaints of burning micturition and urethral discharge after 1 week of unprotected intercourse. Identify the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Urethritis:

  • Gonococcal- Diffuse, yellowish discharge with urinary complaints and constitutional symptoms
  • Nongonococcal- Scanty, watery discharge without urinary complaints

Gonococcal urethritis

  • Causative organism - Neisseria gonorrhoea
  • Incubation period- 1-14 days

Non gonococcal urethritis-

  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycoplasma
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Trichomonas vaginalis

Almost all urethritis patients have penile discharge, gonococcal urethritis can easily be distinguished from NGU by looking for gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If intracellular diplococci are identified, the urethritis is gonococcal; if no diplococci are identified, the diagnosis is classified as NGU.

For non gonococcal urethritis NAAT Nucleic acid amplification test is useful.

Reference: Sexually Transmitted Diseases And HIV/AIDS By Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition

questions.text: Steeple sign on X-ray neck AP view is seen in?
questions.solution:
The "steeple sign" on an X-ray of the neck (AP view) is indicative of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup. Croup is characterized by inflammation of the upper airway, specifically the larynx and trachea, leading to narrowing of the subglottic region and causing the characteristic steeple-like appearance on X-ray.

Other options :

A.Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis causes inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, which leads to a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

C.Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition where the soft tissues of the larynx collapse during inspiration, causing a characteristic "omega-shaped" epiglottis on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

D.Laryngeal web: A laryngeal web is a congenital condition where there is a membrane or web-like structure across the larynx, which may cause respiratory difficulty, but it does not result in the steeple sign on X-ray.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, arose and Throat, And Head and Surgery by Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page no: 507

questions.text: Dystrophin absent and presence of small muscle fibrils cause?
questions.solution:
Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy are the Dystrophinopaties. DMD is characterized by absent dystrophin and Beckers muscular dystrophy is characterized by either decreased level or size of dystrophin.

Total absence of dystrophin points to the diagnosis of DMD.

Biopsy is not diagnostic in myopathies. So the microscopy will be almost same for DMD and BMD. Muscle biopsy in young ages will show degeneration and regeneration of muscle fibres with preserved architecture. There is no active inflammation except for myophagocytosis. As the disease progresses, the muscle fibres are replaced by fatty infiltration. The remaining muscle fibres show varying size from atrophic to hypertrophic.

Immunohistochemical staining shows absence of sarcolemmal staining in DMD and reduced staining in BMD.

They are both XL recessive inheritance. Dystrophin provides stability to the muscle fibre by acting as a bridge between the cytoskeleton inside the muscle fibre and the basement membrane outside the cell. DMD results from deletions or frame shift mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to total absence of the protein, where as BMD results in the formation of truncated variant of dystrophin that leads to partially functional protein.

Reference: Robbins 10th ed 1232-1233

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in glomerular basement membrane:
questions.solution:
Option A & Option B: The keratan sulfates consist of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units containing sulfate attached to the 6′ position of GlcNAc or occasionally of Gal. Keratan sulfate I was originally isolated from the cornea, while keratan sulfate II came from cartilage. The two GAGs differ in the structural links to the core proteins, and as I or II, the classification is based on the different linkage to the core protein. In the eye, they lie between collagen fibrils and play a critical role in corneal transparency. Changes in proteoglycan composition found in corneal scars disappear when the cornea heals.

Option C: Heparan Sulfate is present in a proteoglycan found on many extracellular cell surfaces. It contains GlcN with fewer N-sulfates than heparin, and, unlike heparin, its predominant uronic acid is GlcUA. Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells, with their core proteins actually spanning that membrane. In this, they may act as receptors and may also participate in the mediation of the cell growth and cell-cell communication. The attachment of cells to their substratum in culture is mediated at least in part by heparan sulfate. Heparan sulfate is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney along with type IV collagen and laminin, where it plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.

Option D: Proteoglycans linked to chondroitin sulfate by the Xyl-Ser O-glycosidic bond are prominent components of cartilage. The repeating disaccharide is similar to that found in hyaluronic acid, containing GlcUA but with GalNAc replacing GlcNAc. The GalNAc is substituted with sulfate at either its 4′ or its 6′ position, with approximately one sulfate being present per disaccharide unit. Chondroitin sulfates have an important role in maintaining the structure of the ECM. They are located at sites of calcification in endochondral bone and are a major component of cartilage. They are found in high amounts in the ECM of the central nervous system and, in addition to their structural function, are thought to act as signaling molecules in the prevention of the repair of nerve endings after injury.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 50 PN 603

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that is done to limit the spread of infection in HIV patients?
questions.solution:
• Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one. Cranial cavity is exposed first, followed by thoracic, cervical and abdominal organs. Spinal cord is removed from the back. In this the anatomico-pathologic relations are not preserved.
  • Rokitansky's technique: It involves in situ dissection in part, combined with en block removal. It is preferred choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases, such as HTV, hepatitis B.
  • Lettulle's technique: Cervical, thoracic, adbominal and pelvic organs are removed en masse and dissected as organ block. It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.
  • Ghon's Technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital system are removed as organ blocks. Neuronal system is removed as another block

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology By K S Narayan Reddy, 35th edition.

questions.text: A patient had undergone submandibular gland excision and the wharton's duct was ligated in the process. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be damaged
questions.solution:
The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). It provides sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. During submandibular gland excision, the lingual nerve can be at risk of injury  because it passes close to the gland leading to numbness or altered sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Other options and brief explanations:

A. Inferior alveolar nerve: This nerve supplies sensation to the lower teeth and gums. It is not as likely to be damaged during submandibular gland excision as the lingual nerve.

B. Hypoglossal nerve: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the muscles of the tongue and is not at risk during submandibular gland excision.

D. Nerve to mylohyoid: The nerve to mylohyoid is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (CN V3) and supplies the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric muscles, but it is not at risk during submandibular gland excision.

Reference: Logan Turner's Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear, Head and Neck Surgery, Edited by S. Musheer Hussain, 11th Edition, Page no: 244

The lesion given in the figure depicts a boggy swelling of the scalp with pustules and scarring alopecia, characteristic of Kerion.

questions.text: Identify the injury
questions.solution:
Incised-like or Incised-looking Wounds : Lacerations produced without excessive skin crushing may have relatively sharp margins. Blunt force on areas where the skin is close to bone, and the subcutaneous tissues are scanty, may produce a wound which by linear splitting of the tissues (as the skin is easily stretched during impact), may look like incised wound. The sites are the scalp, eyebrows, cheek bones, lower jaw, iliac crest, perineum, and shin. A wound produced by a fall on the knee or elbow with the limb flexed, and by a broken glass or sharp stone also simulates incised wound.

INCISED WOUNDS: An incised wound (cut, slice) is a clean cut through the tissues, (usually the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels), caused by sharp-edged instrument. The wound is longer than it is deep.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology By K S Narayan Reddy , 35th edition.

questions.text: HIV patient with refractory diarrhea. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli and microsporidia are the common organisms causing diarrhoea in HIV.

Cryptosporidium: CD4 counts <100. May range from self limiting infection to chronic diarrhoea. Cause infection of biliary tree causing cholecystitis and pancreatitis secondary to papillary stenosis. Diagnosis is by demonstration of oocysts in the stools that are acid fast. Treatment is initiation of ART. Nitazoxonide may benefit.

Microsporidia: the commonest organism is Enterocytozoon bineuesi. They are obligate intra cellular parasites of the enteric cells. They are also found in cells outside the GIT like eye, brain, muscle liver etc. They have been associated with conjunctivitis and hepatitis. They need chromotrope based stains for demonstration of the organism in the stools , because of their small size. Electron microscopy of the stool or intestinal aspirate is needed for definitive diagnosis. Treatment is reconstitution of immune system with ART. Albendazole may be effective.

Isospora belli: clinical features are similar to cryptosporidium. More common in tropics and sub tropics. Oocysts are acid fast and are larger in size. Treatment is very easy and effective with TMP-SMX

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed 1569-70

questions.text: A 35 year old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi, which may or may not be associated with heart failure and edema; acute pernicious (fulminating) beriberi (Shoshin beriberi), in which heart failure and metabolic abnormalities predominate, without peripheral neuritis; and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis, which is associated especially with alcohol and narcotic abuse. The role of thiamin diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency there is impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. In subjects on a relatively high carbohydrate diet, this results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, which may cause life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Option B: Although Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is centrally involved in lipid and carbohydrate metabolism, and deficiency occurs in many countries, it is not fatal, because there is very efficient conservation of tissue riboflavin. Riboflavin released by the catabolism of enzymes is rapidly incorporated into newly synthesized enzymes. Deficiency is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation and inflammation of the tongue, and seborrheic dermatitis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option C: Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency can lead to pellagra. It is characterized by a photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrheoa. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Although the nutritional etiology of pellagra is well established, and either tryptophan or niacin prevents or cures the disease, additional factors, including deficiency of riboflavin or vitamin B6, both of which are required for synthesis of nicotinamide from tryptophan, may be important. In most outbreaks of pellagra, twice as many women as men are affected, probably the result of inhibition of tryptophan metabolism by estrogen metabolites.

When staple diet is maize (corn), tryptophan content is low & niacin is in bound form, so unavailable to body, leading to pellagra.

Option D: Although clinical deficiency disease is rare, there is evidence that a significant proportion of the population has marginal vitamin B6 status. Moderate deficiency results in abnormalities of tryptophan and methionine metabolism. Increased sensitivity to steroid hormone action may be important in the development of hormone-dependent cancer of the breast, uterus, and prostate, and vitamin B6 status may affect the prognosis. The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro, expressed as the activation coefficient. Measurement of plasma concentrations of the vitamin is also used.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 44 PN 534

questions.text: Female with 41week gestation confirmed by radiological investigation, very sure of her LMP, no uterine contractions, no effacement and no dilation. What should not be done
questions.solution:
• MgSO is the drug of choice for prevention and management of convulsions in eclampsia.

Mechanism of action:

  • It decreases the acetylcholine release from the nerve endings and decreases the sensitivity of motor end plate to Ach.
  • Blocks the calcium channel and decreases intracranial edema.

Regimens for MgSO4:

  • IM loading dose Pritchard Regimen-5 gm (50% solution) in each buttock deep i.m. maintenance dose - 5 gm (50%) deep i.m. on alternate buttock every 4 hours.
  • IV loading dose 4-6 slow over 3-5 minutes at rate not more than 1 g/min. Maintenance dose - 1-2 gm/hr i.v. infusion

Therapeutic range - 4 to 7 mEq/L

  • There is a narrow range at which therapeutic effect and toxic effects of Magnesium occurs, therefore monitoring for magnesium toxicity is very essential.

Reference: Review of obstetrics by shakshi arora hans, 9th ed, pg no. 250.

questions.text: Middle aged women with b/l proptosis with restricted ocular movement and chemosis is euthyroid. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nonspecific orbital inflammation (NSOI), also known as orbital inflammatory pseudotumor, idiopathic orbital inflammation ( IOI)and orbital inflammatory syndrome is the most common cause of painful orbital mass in adults.[1] NSOI can be localized or diffuse. When localized, inflammation can affect the extraocular muscles (orbital myositis), lacrimal gland (dacryoadenitis), sclera (scleritis), uvea (uveitis), and the superior orbital fissure and cavernous sinus (Tolosa-Hunt syndrome). Others include periscleritis, perineuritis, and mass. When diffuse, NSOI may diffusely involve the orbital fatty tissues. NSOI is the third most common orbital disease after thyroid eye disease and orbital lymphoma.

NSOI can both radiologically and clinically mimic a malignant process. Therefore, it is a diagnosis of exclusion, only after all other causes of inflammation have been eliminated. Treatment options are varied and can include surgery, steroids, chemotherapeutic agents and irradiation patients with suspected NSOI require a full ophthalmic assessment/workup. NSOI is typically characterized by the abrupt onset of pain, proptosis and other inflammatory signs such as swelling and erythema. Unilateral presentation is more typical but bilateral presentations are not uncommonPhysical examination of patients with suspected NSOI involves lid assessment (retraction/lid lag/lagophthalmos), orbital assessment (proptosis), extraocular muscles (restriction), globe (injection/chemosis), and optic nerve function (visual acuity/color plates/relative afferent pupillary defect). Because of the association between rheumatologic disease and NSOI the typical laboratory work-up for suspected NSOI should include a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, thyroid function studies, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibodies, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, angiotensin-converting enzyme level, rapid plasma reagin test, and rheumatoid factor

Reference: Parson, Section IV, p. 264-272

questions.text: Which site of implantation will cause severe vaginal bleeding no sign of rupture ectopic despite 22 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
USG findings in case of ectopic pregnancy:

  • Transvaginal/ultrasound is the investigation most commonly done to diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

Diagnostic features are: -Dutta Obs. 6/e, p 186

  • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with positive pregnancy test.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas (Cul-de-sac).
  • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary.
  • Gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring (Bagel sign/ tubal ring sign).
  • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.

USG + b-hCG: When USG findings are combined with b-hCG values: it gives a greater accuracy for diagnosing ectopic pregnancy.

  • An intrauterine sac should be visible by transvaginal ultrasound when the b HCG level is approximately 1500-2000IU/L and by transabdominal ultrasound approximately 1 week later, when the b-HCG level is 6000-6500 mIU/ml. If empty uterine cavity is seen with a b-hCG titer above this threshold, an ectopic pregnancy should be suspected.

Reference: Review of obstetrics by dr. shakshi arora hans. 9th ed, pg no 128

questions.text: Q-SOFA components is?

SOFA score aids physicians in identifying sepsis/ septic shock at the bed side by the SEPSIS 3 clinical criteria. SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment score )is a 24 point measurement of major organ dysfunction(Renal, cardiac, pulmonary, neurological, hematological and hepatic), where 0-4 points are assigned for each organ system.

The SEPSIS 3 clinical criteria include:

  1. A suspected or documented infection.
  2. Acute increase in≥ 2 Sepsis related organ failure assessment points.(SOFA)

The qSOFA(Quick SOFA) is a simplified and validated criteria introduced by the SEPSIS 3 which predicts poor out come for hospitalized patients with sepsis.

It includes only three parameters and each if present will be given a score of 1.

  1. GCS<15
  2. RR>20
  3. SBP<100

questions.text: Which of the following is included in essential major blood culture criteria for infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
This question deals with the Dukes criteria for diagnosis of IE.

There are 3 types of microorganisms causing IE.

  1. Typical microorganisms: Viridans streptococcus, Staph Gallolyticus, HACEK organisms, staph aureus, community acquired enterococci in the absence of a primary focus.
  2. Other Microorganism consistent with causing IE
  3. Coxiella burnetti
  4. Contaminants: Diphtheroids, CoNS

For group 1 two separate blood cultures should be positive

For group 2 blood cultures drawn 12 hours apart or or all of 3 blood cultures or more than or equal to 4 cultures of which the first and the last drawn at least 1h apart

For group 3, we need only a single positive culture or a IgG titre >1:800

For group 4 repeated cultures should be consistently positive to satisfy major criteria.

Three two bottle culture sets should be taken for culture from separate venepuncture sites over one to two hours.

2 major and one minor

Or

One major and three minor criteria is required for definitive diagnosis of IE

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed Pg 1026

questions.text: Which of the following is false as physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Residual volume decreases due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the enlarging uterus.

  • Lung volumes such as functional residual capacity (FRC) and residual volume (RV) are reduced.

Explanation for other options:

Increased cardiac output (Option A): During pregnancy, cardiac output increases by approximately 30-50%. This is due to a rise in both stroke volume and heart rate, which helps meet the increased metabolic demands of the mother and growing fetus.

Decreased total protein (Option B): There is a physiological haemodilution in pregnancy caused by a greater increase in plasma volume compared to red cell mass. As a result, the concentration of total plasma proteins, including albumin, decreases.

Increased GFR (Option D): Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases by 40-50% in pregnancy. This is due to enhanced renal plasma flow and hormonal influences, and it supports increased excretion of maternal and fetal waste products.

Reference: Review of obstetrics by shakshi arora hans, 9th ed, pg no. 128

questions.text: The Immunoglobulin structure (Pentamer) shown in the figure belongs to which class of antibody?
questions.solution:
Ig M is pentameric immunoglobulin with five - four peptide subunits.

The subunits are joined by j chain.

J chain is found in Ig A and Ig M

Ig M is the most efficient antibody which fixes complement by classical pathways.

Ig M is elevated in primary immune response.

Ig M in transported thorugh placenta, so presense of Ig M indicates intrauterine infection.

questions.text: C wave in JVP is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A wave represents atrial systole, occurs along with S4, preceding theS1. a wave will be hence absent in atrial fibrillation. A prominent a wave will be seen when the atria contracts against a non compliant right ventricle. Canon a wave occurs in AV dissociation, where the atria contracts against a closed ventricle, as ion Ventricular tachycardia.

X decent indicates a fall in the right atrial pressure, after the atrial systole. During this time, the tricuspid valves close and the valve is pushed into the atria, resulting in a small positive c wave, which interrupts the x decent. Hence it correlated with S1.

Immediately after the closure of the tricuspid valve, the ventricular systole begins, during which time, the atria is relaxed and the atrial filling takes place.

The atrial filling is represented by the v wave in JVP. When the filling of the atria is increased the v wave will be accentuated. In tricuspid regurgitation, the tricuspid valves fail to close properly hence the c wave will merge with the v wave to form giant v wave or the v wave is vetricularized.

The y decent indicates the rapid filling of the ventricles. In tricuspid regurgitation, the y decent will be rapid. In conditions where the RV compliance is reduced or the tricuspid valve is stenosed, the y decent will be prolonged.

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed 1817

Even If there is needle stick injury, It should be started as soon as possible.

Viral load is one parameter which is helpful to monitor effect of HAART.

questions.text: 50 years old male presented with fatiguability for one year. Evaluation showed mild anemia, massive splenomegaly. Hb- 10gm%, ILC of 120 x 10(3), platelet 500 x 10(3), neutrophils 60, basophils 4, eosinophils 6, lymphocytes 15. Also seen were myeloblasts, myelocytes metamyelocytes and bands. M: E ratio 8:1. What is the most sensitive investigation?
questions.solution:
The age, the symptoms and the presence of massive splenomegaly points towards a myeloproliferative disorder. From the peripheral smear, we can see that there there is an increase in neutrophils with a shift to left having band forms, myelocytes and metamyelocytes and an increased in myeloid erythroid ratio classical of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia.

The cytogenetic abnormality seen in 90% of patients with CML is the reciprocal translocation between chromosome 9 and 22. This translocation can be identified by the technique of FISH and PCR.

Immunophenotyping is a process used to identify the cells based on the antigens on their surface. It cant be used for identifying chromosomal anomalies.

FDG PET is the imaging technique used to identify areas of increased metabolism as in malignancy or infections. It can help us to identify the organ involved, but doesn't help in identifying the type of disease.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase measures the alkaline phosphatase in neutrophils.

Its value is high in leukemoid reaction, tissue damage, steroid use, OCP, aplastic anemia, hodgkins lymphoma and Down syndrome. It is elevated in myeloproliferative disorders, but is low in chronic phase of CML.it is low in PNH and hereditiary hypophosphatemia.

Reference: Harrisons 21st ed 819, de Gruchis hematology 5th ed 186

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with increasing abdominal girth and decreased liver span. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with eosinophilic material cytokeratin positive. What is the content of the inclusions?
questions.solution:
In a chronic alcoholic patient with deceased liver span the diagnosis is Alcoholic liver disease which can be steatosis, hepatitis or cirrhosis. In a patient who continues to consume alcohol, a combination of the three can be seen.

Alcoholic steatosis is characterised by the presence of microvesicular steatosis.

Alcoholic hepatitis is characterised by

  1. Ballooned hepatocytes, where the hepatocytes are damaged with cleared out cytoplasm and with extensive cytoskeletal damage resulting in eosinophilic bodies called Mallory Hyaline , which are intermediary filaments-Keratin 8 and Keratin I8(Hence they stain positive for cytokeratin)
  2. Inflammation and necrosis
  3. Perivenular fibrosis: initially appear as chicken wire fibrosis. Later leads to periportal and bridging fibrosis known as Laennec Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis liver is characterised microscopically by the presence of parenchymal nodules surrounded by areas of fibrosis throughout the liver, resulting in the formation of nodules. Fibrosis can be stained using Masons Trichrome.

So, under light microscope the intermediary filaments appear as Mallory hyaline which are seen collapsed into the cell and they stain positive for cytokeratin.

Reference: Robins&Cotran 10th ed843-845

questions.text: Mrs Rekha having her child of 2 years presents with pruritus vulvae & amenorrhea. She gives h/o severe blood loss & failure of lactation during pregnancy. She is lethargic and has cold intolerance, she has multiple skin infections and anemia. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Sheehan syndrome occurs when the anterior pituitary gland is damaged due to significant blood loss. Classically, this happens after delivery, in which the mother loses a significant amount of blood. This blood loss results in the pituitary gland not being able to produce hormones.

The symptoms of Sheehan syndrome occur as a result of the low hormone levels. These may include an inability to produce breast milk, irregular or absent periods, hot flashes and a decreased sex drive. Other symptoms may include fatigue, headaches, low blood pressure and hair loss.

Excessive blood loss during or after delivery of a baby may affect the function of the pituitary gland, leading to a form of maternal hypopituitarism known as Sheehan syndrome(SS). Such extensive bleeding may reduce the blood flow to the pituitary gland causing the pituitary cells to be damaged or die(necrosis).

Reference: Review of obstetrics by dr. Shakshi arora hans, ed. 9th, pg no. 228

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of donovanosis?
questions.solution:
Donovanosis is also knows granuloma inguinale, it is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram negative bacterium klebsiella granulomatis(formerly know as calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

Sign and symptoms include one or more painless lumps, usually in the genital, anal region or groin. The lump slowly gets larger and then ulcerates. These sores typically bleed easily, have a rolled edge and are beefy red in colour. In some cases the sore has an offensive smell.

Lab diagnosis – IN lab Donovan bodies are seen. They are rod shaped, oval organisms that can be seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear phagocytes or histiocytes in tissue samples form patients with granuloma inguinale. They appear deep purple when stained with wright's stain.

Reference: ANanthanarayan 9th 467

questions.text: Spot the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of pex

Diagnosis is made using slit lamp biomicroscopy and intraocular pressure measurement. Deposition of white fluffy material on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin and iris transillumination defects can be visualized in many cases. Gonioscopy may show increased pigment deposit on the trabecular meshwork.

Physical examination

Signs

Increased intraocular pressure

Possible glaucomatous damage to optic nerve

Poor dilation with peripupillary transillumination defect

Fibrillar white flaky deposits on the anterior lens capsule(Hoarfrost Ring)

Fibrillar white flaky deposits on at pupillary border

Hyperpigmentation of the trabecular meshwork(TM) with an open angle on gonioscopy

Sampaolesi line, abundance of linear pigment anterior to the TM at or anterior to Schwalbe's line(not pathogonomic; also seen in pigment dispersion syndrome)

Symptoms

No associated symptoms aside from possibly with significantly increased intraocular pressure

Reference: Parson, Section IV, P. 147-150

Hair perforation test consists of inoculating colonies of an organism into dish containing a small amount of water a few drops of yeast extract solution and some human hair dish is incubated at 30 degree celcius and after 7 days some hair are taken and kept on a slid with cover slip and observed under microscope. The test is considered positive if the hair has deep, narrow wedge shaped perforation in it.

questions.text: A patient with loss of right half of the visual field loss on both sides. What would the probable diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
Lesions of the optic nerve will result in total blindness in the ipsilateral eye.

Lesion of the optic chiasm will lead to bitemporal hemianopia.

Lesion of the optic tract and beyond will lead to contraleteral homonymous hemiaopia

Damage to the optic radiations in the temporal lobe(Meyer's loop) produces a superior quadrantic homonymous hemianopia (lesion marked as J).

Injury to the optic radiations in the parietal lobe results in an inferior quadrantic homonymous hemianopia(K).

Lesions of the primary visual cortex give rise to dense, congruous hemianopic field defects. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery supplying the occipital lobe is a common cause of total homonymous hemianopia. Some patients have macular sparing, because the central field representation at the tip of the occipital lobe is supplied by collaterals from the middle cerebral artery(L).

Destruction of both occipital lobes produces cortical blindness. This condition can be distinguished from bilateral prechiasmal visual loss by noting that the pupil responses and optic fundi remain normal.

Reference: Harrison 21st ed Pages 218-219

questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it?
questions.solution:
Option A: A defect in mismatch repair can leads to Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer(HNPCC).

Option B: A defect in Base excision repair can leads to MUTYH-associated polyposis(MAP).

Option C: A defect in Nucleotide excision repair can leads to Xeroderma pigmentosum(XP), Cockayne syndrome(CS) & Trichothiodystrophy(TTD).

Option D: A defect in Homologus recombinant repair can leads to Ataxia Telagiectasia(AT) -like disorder, Nijmegen breakage syndrome(NBS), Bloom syndrome(BS), Werner syndrome(WS), Rothmund-Thomson syndrome(RTS) and Breast cancer susceptibility 1 and 2(BRCA1, BRCA2).

Repair of damaged DNA is critical for maintaining genomic integrity and thereby preventing the propagation of mutations, either horizontally(somatic cells) or vertically(germ cells). DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical and biologic assaults on a daily basis, hence efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions is essential. Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways. The mechanisms of DNA repair include nucleotide excision repair (NER); mismatch repair(MMR); base excision repair(BER); homologous recombination(HR); and nonhomologous end-joining(NHEJ) repair pathways

There are many diseases are associated with defective DNA repair mechanism:

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 35 PN 370

questions.text: Where is the likely lesion if patient cannot see right visual field images from both eyes?
questions.solution:
Lesions of optic tract

The optic tract is a continuation of the optic nerve that relays information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus(LGN), pretectal nuclei and superior colliculus. The optic tract represents the first stage in the visual pathway in which visual information is transferred in a homonymous nature. Main characteristic feature of lesion involving whole optic tract is homonymous hemianopsia. A lesion in the left optic tract will cause right-sided homonymous hemianopsia, while a lesion in the right optic tract will cause left-sided homonymous hemianopsia.

Causes

The optic tract syndrome is characterized by a contralateral, incongruous homonymous hemianopia, contralateral relative afferent pupillary defect(RAPD) and optic atrophy due to retrograde axonal degeneration. Causes of optic tract lesions are also classified into intrinsic and extrinsic forms. Intrinsic lesions include demyelinating diseases and infarction. Such lesions produce optic tract syndrome type II Extrinsic or compressive lesions are caused by pituitary craniopharyngioma, tumours of optic thalamus. Other causes include syphilitic meningitis, gumma and tubercular meningitis etc.

Signs and symptoms

Incongruous homonymous hemianopia.

Wernicke's pupillary reaction- No pupillary reaction when light shown to the blind half of retina, but if light is shown to seeing half, pupil shows reaction.

Reference: khurana 4/e, P. 121

questions.text: An one month old baby comes with watering eyes and a cloudy cornea. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Buphthalmos(plural: buphthalmoses) is enlargement of the eyeball and is most commonly seen in infants and young children. It is sometimes referred to as buphthalmia(plural buphthalmias).[2] It usually appears in the newborn period or the first 3 months of life.[3] and in most cases indicates the presence of congenital(infantile) glaucoma, which is a disorder in which elevated pressures within the eye lead to structural eye damage and vision loss.

Signs and symptoms

Buphthalmos in itself is merely a clinical sign and does not generate symptoms. Patients with glaucoma often initially have no symptoms; later, they can exhibit excessive tearing(lacrimation) and extreme sensitivity to light(photophobia). On ophthalmologic exam, a doctor can detect increased intraocular pressure, distortion of the optic disc and corneal edema, which manifests as haziness.

Other symptoms include a prominent eyeball, Haab's striae tear in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea, an enlarged cornea and myopia.

Reference: Parson, Section IV, P. 288-300

questions.text: Test for diagnosis of HSV encephalitis
questions.solution:
The primary diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis is CSF PCR. It is 96% sensitive and 99% specific. It has got a fairly high negative predictive value, if the pre test probability of HSV is low. It is not affected by anti viral treatment for up to 7 days. Only 20% CSF samples will be positive after 2 weeks of illness.

The CSF antibody testing also aids in diagnosis of herpes simplex virus encephalitis. But the detection of antigens and antibodies typically occurs after one week of the infection, which makes acute diagnosis impossible with antibodies. Useful in patients with more than one week of infection and in whom CSF PCR is negative.

Reference: Harrisons 21st Pg 1102-1111

questions.text: A female comes with a year old history of contact lens present with eye pain, irritation and foreign body sensation. spot the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant papillary conjunctivitis(GPC) is when the inside of your eyelid gets red, swollen and irritated. Without GPC, the inside of your eyelid is very smooth.

People who wear contact lenses(especially soft lenses) have the greatest chance of getting GPC. GPC can happen at any time, even after wearing contacts for many years.

People who do not wear contact lenses can also get GPC. But this is rare, mostly affecting those who have an artificial eye or stitches.

In giant papillary conjunctivitis, large bumps appear on the underside of the eyelid.

GPC Causes

GPC seems to be caused by the following:

  • An allergy, either to contact lenses or the chemicals used to clean them. Contact lens wearers with asthma, hay fever or other allergies are more likely to get GPC.
  • A contact lens, artificial eye or exposed stitches rubbing against the eyelid
  • Deposits of proteins or other substances on the contact lenses
  • Chronic eye allergies

Reference: Kanski 8/e.

Haab striae(Discrete corneal opacities appear as lines with double contour due to rupture in Descemets membrane)

Cornea is hazy with frosted glass appearance.

Lens is antero-posteriorly flat and may be subluxated backward

Variable cupping and atrophy of disc

questions.text: Patient with general fatigue, tiredness. Primary clinical examination is uneventful. Normal TLC and DLC. No immature cells were seen. Superficial discrete lymph nodes were enlarged. biopsy showed effaced architecture, indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Cd10 and bcl2 positive. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Greater than 85% of follicular lymphomas have a characteristic(14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14. This chromosomal rearrangement results in the inappropriate "overexpression" of BCL2 protein, which you will recall is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

Lymph nodes usually are effaced by a distinctly nodular proliferation(Fig.). Most commonly, the predominant neoplastic cells are so-called "centrocytes", cells slightly larger than resting lymphocytes that have angular "cleaved" nuclei with prominent indentations and linear infoldings(Fig.). The nuclear chromatin is coarse and condensed and nucleoli are indistinct. These centrocytes are mixed with variable numbers of centroblasts, larger cells with vesicular chromatin, several nucleoli and modest amounts of cytoplasm. In most tumors, centroblasts are a minor component of the overall cellularity, mitoses are infrequent and single necrotic cells(cells undergoing apoptosis) are not seen. These features help to distinguish follicular lymphoma from follicular hyperplasia, in which mitoses and apoptosis are prominent. Uncommonly, large cells predominate, a histologic pattern that correlates with a more aggressive clinical behavior.

Immunopheno type

These tumors express B cell markers such as CD20 and the germinal center B cell markers CD10 and BCL6; of note, BCL6 is a transcription factor that is required for the generation of germinal center B cells.

Clinical Features

Follicular lymphoma mainly occurs in adults older than 50 years of age and affects males and females equally. It usually manifests as painless, generalized lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow is involved at diagnosis in approximately 80% of cases.

Follicular lymphoma-lymph node.

  1. Nodular aggregates of lymphoma cells are present throughout.
  2. At high magnification, small lymphoid cells with condensed chromatin and irregular or cleaved nuclear outlines(centrocytes) are mixed with a population of larger cells with nucleoli(centroblasts).

Reference: Robbins, 10th ed, Pg 469

questions.text: APGAR score 3 at 1 minute indicates:
questions.solution:

4-6 = Moderately depressed

questions.text: The drug buspirone, used in cases of anxiety, acts as an agonist on the receptor
questions.solution:
Buspirone It is the first azapirone, a class of selective antianxiety drugs, distinctly different from BZDs. Buspirone:

  • Does not produce significant sedation or cognitive/functional impairment.
  • Does not interact with BZD receptor or modify GABAergic transmission.
  • Does not produce tolerance or dependence; no rebound anxiety or withdrawal symptoms on stoppage.
  • Does not suppress BZD or barbiturate withdrawal syndrome.
  • Has no muscle relaxant or anticonvulsant activity.

The mechanism of anxiolytic action is not clearly known, but may be dependent on its selective partial agonistic action on 5-HT1A receptors. By stimulating presynaptic 5-HT1A autoreceptors, it reduces the activity of dorsal raphe serotonergic neurones.

Reference: Kdt 8th/e P. 495

questions.text: Which of the following is included in form of thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Form of thought disorder, also known as formal thought disorder, refers to disturbances in the way thoughts are organized and expressed. It is commonly seen in conditions like schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. One of the features of form of thought disorder is "derailment" or "loose associations". In derailment, the person's thoughts jump from one unrelated topic to another, making it difficult to follow a coherent and logical flow of ideas.

Other Options:

B. Obsession - Obsessions are intrusive and distressing thoughts, images, or urges that cause significant anxiety and are typically associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder(OCD). While they represent a type of psychological symptom, they are not included in the form of thought disorder.

C. Thought insertion - Thought insertion is a delusional belief that external forces or entities are placing thoughts into one's mind. It is not directly related to the form of thought disorder.

D. Delusion - Delusions are fixed false beliefs that are not based in reality and are characteristic of various psychotic disorders. While they are related to thought disturbances, they are not part of the form of thought disorder itself.

Reference: New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, Edited by John R. Geddes, Nancy C. Andreasen and Guy M. Goodwin, Third Edition, Page no. 46

questions.text: Identify the infection from the chest X-ray of patient with low grade fever?
questions.solution:
Given x-ray shows randomly distributed lung nodules which is highly suggestive of miliary TB.

Miliary TB can arise as a result of progressive primary infection or reactivation of a latent focus with subsequent spread via the blood stream. It is potentially fatal form of TB that results from massive lymphohematogenous dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli. High resolution CT is more sensitive and shows randomly distributed miliary nodules.

The clinical manifestations are nonspecific and can be obscure till late in the disease.

Constellation of symptoms and signs suggestive of miliary TB:

  • Peripheral lymphadenopathy
  • Skin lesions
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Pleural, pericardial effusions, ascites
  • Choroid tubercles(fundoscopy)

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology, page no 2318

questions.solution:
Workers in industries that produce aniline dyes, rubber, plastic, textiles and cable have high incidence of bladder cancer. Bladder cancer may occur in workers in these factories after a prolonged exposure of about 20 years. The carcinogenic substances responsible for bladder cancer in these cases are the metabolites of β-naphthylamine and benzene.

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following can be seen in this child?
A. Bilious vomiting
B. Visible peristalsis from left to right/Palpable mass
C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia
D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
• Nonbilious vomiting is the initial symptom of pyloric stenosis. The vomiting may or may not be projectile initially but is usually progressive, occurring immediately after a feeding. Emesis might follow each feeding or it may be intermittent. The vomiting usually starts after 3 wk of age, but symptoms can develop as early as the 1st wk of life and as late as the 5th months.
  • As vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ion and chloride leads to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • The diagnosis has traditionally been established by palpating the pyloric mass. The mass is firm, movable, approximately 2 cm in length, olive shaped, hard, best palpated from the left side and located above and to the right of the umbilicus in the mid-epigastrium beneath the liver’s edge. The olive is easiest palpated after an episode of vomiting. After feeding, there may be a visible gastric peristaltic wave that progresses across the abdomen.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., Pg. 1797

questions.text: Carbapenem with maximum seizure risk is:
questions.solution:
Carbapenems

These include imipenem, doripenem, meropenem, faropenem and ertapenem.

These have wide spectrum of activity including gram positive cocci, gram negative rods as well as anaerobes. For the treatment of pseudomonas(meropenem is most active whereas ertapenem is least) infections, these drugs should be combined with aminoglycosides.

Carbapenems are β-lactamase resistant and are drugs of choice for Enterobacter, Klebsiella and acinetobacter species. These are the only β-lactams which are reliably efficacious against ESBL (extended spectrum β-lactamase) producing organisms and are thus drug of choice for ESBL-producing bacteria. Imipenem is rapidly inactivated by renal dehydropeptidase I, so it is combined with cilastatin, an inhibitor of this enzyme. Cilastatin increases the half life of imipenem and also inhibits the formation of nephrotoxic metabolite.

Main adverse effects of imipenem-cilastatin combination include seizures and gastrointestinal distress. Meropenem, doripenem and ertapenem are not metabolized by renal dehydropeptidase and are less likely to cause seizures. Ertapenem is very long acting and is inactive against Pseudomonas.

Reference: Kdt 8th/e p782
